newsitem.title: USA: More storms could exacerbate Illinois River floods.
newsitem.headline: More storms could exacerbate Illinois River floods.

text.p: More rain is expected in the Illinois River watershed next week, posing the threat of further flooding in the area, meteorologists said.

Mike Palmerino, senior agricultural meteorologist with Weather Services Corp, said rain-bearing systems were forecast to be moving across the area on Saturday, late Monday into Tuesday and next Friday.
"I don't they are particularly bad systems in terms of snow disrupting livestock transportation but I think they will be continuing to create problems on the Illinois River," Palmerino said.

Three stretches of the Illinois River remained closed to navigation Friday due to high water, a U.S. Coast Guard official said. They were closed on Wednesday to protect houses and properaties in low-lying areas.
WSC's Palmerino said he was forecasting about 0.5 to 1.0 inch of rain in the watershed of the Illinois River on Saturday.

Tim Bowden, meteorologist with Weather Express Inc, forecast there would be 0.25 to 0.75 inch Saturday around the Illinois River, then 0.1 to 0.5 inches Monday/Tuesday. The system late next week "doesn't look too strong" he noted.
"They (the rain systems) are going to keep flooding concerns very very likely next week," said WSC's Palmerino.
He also noted that if conditions remain wet then concern about corn planting delays may begin to develop.
"As we now turn the calender into March, I think people will start to looking at it in terms of beginning to hold up plantings," Palmerino said.
"It is very early but I think that if this pattern continues and shows no sign of drying up that you will begin to see concern regarding the ability to get the corn crop planted," he added.
Analysts said corn planting in the U.S. Midwest normally takes place around mid-April to mid-May.
